advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> 1ST. U.S. ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Each picture represents a customers target. Three of them are well known: Home/entertainement, office and educational uses. A fourth one is added for the first time, the senior citizens. Epson thought the QX-10 was user-friendly enough to be used by retired people. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> <b>The All-Purpose System</b> <br><br> The MTX Series is a new departure in micro-computer technology. Whether your needs as a user ore for personal programming, games playing, scientific or process control, educational or business use the MTX Series is already capable or very easily adoptable to almost every application. Glance through the standard features below - you'll see what we mean.<br><br> <b>Software</b><br> The MTX's 24K ROM contains several languages and routines which enable the novice or the experienced programmer to make full use of the machine. Standard languages are MTX BASIC, MTX LOGO commands, NODDY. ROM routines include on ASSSEMBLER/DISASSEMBLER with screen display of the Z80 CPU registers, memory and program, which can be manipulated from the keyboard. Machine code programs can be stepped through one instruction at a time, and easily called from within BASIC programs. A further feature is the Virtual Screen facility which enables the programmer to split the screen into a maximum of eight sections to work independently whilst maIntaining all full screen facilities. Pascal is available as on add-on ROM pock.<br><br> <b>Hardware - 32K RAM on the MTX500. 64K on the MTX512.</b><br> The MTX500 has 32K of user RAM as standard (64K on the 512), expandable to 512K plus 16K of video RAM, controlled by a separate Video Processor. Sixteen colours, 40 column text, 256 x 192 high resolution graphics with all sixteen colours available, and 32 easily moveable user defined graphics characters (Sprites) combine to make effective screen displays quick and simple to achieve. Standard outputs are centronics printer port, two ioystick ports, an uncommitted I/O port, 2400 Baud Cassette port, separate TV and Video Monitor ports, 4 channel sound with hifi output plus a dedicated cartridge port. Other standard features include the Z80A processor runnIng at 4MHz, real time clock, full moving key keyboard with 79 keys including eight 2-function keys and separate numeric pad.<br><br> <b>The Disc Based Computers from Memotech.</b> Designed to use the full power of the MTX computers the FDX and HDX make perfect busIness systems at prices which make perfect business sense. Both feature the CP/M operating system, giving Instant access to a wide range of proven application software. Available in October these feature:<br> • Full Western Digital floppy dIsc controller set with SASI interface for 4 drives, CP/M types 0 - 13.<br> • minimal latency, very high data transfer rates<br> • optional Colour 80 Column Board<br> • optional SilIcon Discs (1/4 Mb) which dramatically Increase the efficiency of 8 bit software to those of 16/32 bit software; increases life and reliability of mechanical drive<br> • permits single disc CP/M operation<br><br> <b>FDX Floppy Disc System</b><br> 1 or 2 5 1/4" Qume drives 500K unformatted, 347K formatted.<br> <b>HDX- Hard Disc System</b><br> 5 1/4" Qume drive, 500K unformatted, 347K formatted, 5 1/4" Winchester which may be 5, 10, or 20 Mb.</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>February 1983<br><br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> For years, people have been trying to build a better Apple II.<br> It finally happened.<br> Meet the Apple IIe, an impressive new version of a most impressive machine.<br> The 'e' means enhanced. Which means a bundle of new features...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In U.K., at 1986 Christmas period, the 1040 STF was sold £799 + VAT for the 12" monochrome version, and £999 + VAT for the 14" colour version.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> OHIO BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERTISING PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ARGENTINIAN ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.speccy.org/czarg/" target="_blank">CZARG</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE FRONT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Description of the complete Atmos system.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PHILIPS FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>Two generations amazed...</b> <br><br> Perhaps a bit too much though... but the scene is beautiful and we can only admire the originality of the Philips' communication campaign which, for once, is not exclusively focused on the young Basic apprentices.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 84)</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The Laser 200, a Secam color micro-computer really very suprising''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ORANGE+ US AD. (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to <a href="http://www.textfiles.com" target="_blank">www.textfiles.com</a> for this scan</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">You may not have thought of all the reasons for buying a personal computer. There are exciting games, of course, but what about financial management, household records, even income tax? You need a versatile, sophisticated machine that's as limitless as your imagination. You need the Compucolor ll...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST US AD.</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NOT REALLY AN IMSAI!</strong></font><br><blockquote>In october 1979, the IMSAI company went bankrupt. The IMSAI brand name and the spare parts stock were sold to the <b>Fischer-Freitas</b> Company. <br><br> This 1982 advert shows a Z80 CP/M based computer Fisher-Freitas tried to sell with the IMSAI name, without success.<br><br> Fisher-Freitas is still selling original parts for the 8080 model! and continue maintaining a nice 8080 history web site (see the Web links section).</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACORN AD. #3 (NOV. 86)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The BBC Master Compact's educational software, takes children from their first grasp of words and numbers to A-level and beyond.<br> In 84% of U.K. schools, children are already growing up with BBC micros.<br> With a BBC Master Compact at home, your child's ability with computers will progress in leaps and bounds... </font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DICK SMITH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Price list close-up in Australian$:<br> Basic CAT computer X-7500 <b>$1195.00</b><br> Disk Drive X-7505 <b>$1495.00</b><br> Disk Controller X-7510 <b>$149.95</b><br> Emulator Cartridge X-7530 <b>$149.95</b><br> Dual Joysticks X-7520 <b>$49.95</b><br> RF Modulator X-7550 <b>$49.95</b><br> RS-232C Serial Adaptor X-7515 <b>$149.95</b><br> Printer Cable (Centronics) X-7540 <b>$844.95</b><br> Filer Utilities Disk with DOS & Manual X-7512 <b>$59.95</b><br> High resolution RVB monitor X-1193 <b>$995.00</b><br> RGB Cable X-7560 <b>$44.95</b><br> High Res. Green Monitor X-1220 <b>$395.00</b></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD (JULY, 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Eric Buczynski for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #2 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">What in the name of Adam do people do with Apple computers?<br> You tell us.<br> In a thousand of words or less.<br> If your story is original and intriguing enough, you can win a one-week trip to Hawaii. Which is the closest we could come to paradise.</font><br><br> Unfortunately, the contest ended March 31, 1980... </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #2 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Compare the built-in features of leading microcomputers with the Atari personal computers. And go ahead, compare apples and oranges. Their most expensive against our least expensive: the Atari 400...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
This console is only a prototype designed in 1980 by designer Iain Sinclair for Promotors Ltd based in Hong-Kong. It's unclear if this particular model has ever been produced or not, but chances are not.
What is striking is the ressemblance between this prototype and Emerson Arcadia 2001 or Interton VC-4000 compatible systems: two detachable controllers made of a keypad and an analog joystick, several buttons on the control panel...
But the most obvious hint is that all these obscure clone systems were also made in Asia and mainly in Hong-Kong. It sounds like this Palladium Game Console was one of those systems intended to be sold worldwide under different brand names.
The name of this system is not to be confused with German company Palladium which also marketed an Arcadia 2001 clone, the Palladium Video-Computer-Game. Or are both systems linked in any way?
___________
Thanks to Iain Sinclair Design for the pictures.
computer.keyboard: two detachable controllers composed of a 16-button keypad and an analog joystick
computer.name: Palladium Game Console

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> PALLADIUM GAME CONSOLE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.iainsinclair.com" target="_blank">Iain Sinclair Design</a> for the pictures</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CLIPPED CONTROLLERS</strong></font><br><blockquote>Apparently the controllers could be clipped together (for special games ?)<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.iainsinclair.com" target="_blank">Iain Sinclair Design</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>
